query: Which municipality is the largest in Brazil?

nodes.label: forest
nodes.description: A dense collection of trees covering a relatively large area

nodes.label: afforestation
nodes.description: establishment of a forest or stand of trees in an area where there was no previous tree cover

nodes.label: peat
nodes.description: Peat is the first step in the formation of coal, exhibiting the lowest carbon content of less than 60%. It slowly becomes lignite after pressure and temperature increase.

nodes.label: salinization
nodes.description: Increasing evaporation from rising temperatures leads to the salinization of soil and water. Salts accumulate in the soils of arid environments.

nodes.label: Drought forecasting systems
nodes.description: Drought forecasting systems use models fed by climatic and atmospheric data (historical/seasonal weather patterns, real-time meteorological monitoring, and weather forecasts) to predict the probability of a drought occurring in a region or area of interest in the future (up to approximately three months). Drought forecasting systems are an important part of early warning systems, as they provide lead-time to planners for threat responses, which helps minimize drought impact risk.

nodes.label: carbon dioxide
nodes.description: Chemical compound and greenhouse gas that comes from the extraction and burning of fossil fuels (e.g. coal, oil, and natural gas), from wildfires, and natural processes like volcanic eruptions. It is made up of one carbon atom and two oxygen atoms.

nodes.label: risk
nodes.description: Risk is the potential for adverse consequences resulting from the dynamic interplay between (climate-related) hazards, exposure, and vulnerability of affected human or ecological systems.

nodes.label: wildfire
nodes.description: Wildfires are any unplanned or uncontrolled fire affecting natural, cultural, industrial and residential landscapes. Changing weather conditions associated with global warming increase the probability of wildfires.

nodes.label: tropical forests
nodes.description: generic forest in the tropics

nodes.label: extreme weather
nodes.description: Extreme weather refers to events where a weather variable exceeds (or falls below) a threshold. Meaning it is significantly different from the average or usual weather pattern.

nodes.label: woodland
nodes.description: Low-density forest forming open habitats with plenty of sunlight and limited shade

nodes.label: sustainable development goal 15
nodes.description: SDG15: life on land

nodes.label: drought
nodes.description: A drought is an extended period of unusually dry weather marked by a significant and sustained lack of precipitation, falling below a specific threshold over a large area for more than a month

nodes.label: Reduced impact logging
nodes.description: Logging techniques that result in significantly less damage to the surrounding forest and forest ecosystem. Examples of RIL include directional felling, trimming of inter-crown vines, and careful road planning.

nodes.label: reforestation
nodes.description: natural or intentional restocking of existing forests and woodlands that have been depleted

nodes.label: forestry
nodes.description: science and craft of creating, managing, using, conserving and repairing forests, woodlands, and associated resources for human and environmental benefits

nodes.label: rainforest
nodes.description: type of forest with high rainfall

nodes.label: forestry sector
nodes.description: Activities that relate to the production of goods and services from forests.

nodes.label: land degradation
nodes.description: A negative trend in the condition of land, expressed as long-term reduction or loss of at least one of the following: biological productivity, ecological integrity or value to humans.

nodes.label: adaptation
nodes.description: The process of adjusting to living in a changing climate. This can include altering behaviour, systems, and ways of life to reduce or avoid both current and future harms from climate impacts.

nodes.label: gasoline
nodes.description: A fuel that is made up of a mixture of volatile, flammable liquid hydrocarbons derived from petroleum

nodes.label: greenhouse gas
nodes.description: Greenhouse gases are molecules in our atmosphere that absorb heat radiating from Earth’s surface, preventing it from being emitted into space.

nodes.label: desertification
nodes.description: Land degradation in arid, semi-arid and dry sub-humid areas (drylands) resulting from various factors, including climatic variations and human activities.

nodes.label: timber production
nodes.description: activities involved in harvesting, processing, and distributing wood and wood-based products for construction, paper production, and other uses

nodes.label: increasing temperatures
nodes.description: Earth's temperature has risen since 1850 due to human induced climate change. Increasing temperatures intensify the hydrologic cycle, causing dry regions to become drier and wet regions to become wetter.

nodes.label: Drought risk mapping
nodes.description: Drought risk mapping helps identify the areas most at risk of droughts, allowing communities to plan, as well as prepare for and mitigate possible impacts. Drought risk is calculated as the probability of negative impact caused by interactions between hazard (probability of future drought events occurring based on past, current and projected drought conditions), exposure (scale of assets and population in the area) and vulnerability (probability of assets and population being affected by droughts in the area).

nodes.label: flood
nodes.description: Floods are the inundation of normally dry land, resulting from a mix of hydrology, climate, and human factors, varying by type and region.

nodes.label: ocean acidification
nodes.description: Ocean acidification refers to a reduction in the pH of the ocean over an extended period of time, caused primarily by uptake of carbon dioxide (CO2) from the atmosphere.

nodes.label: mitigation
nodes.description: Reducing the emission of and quantity of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere. This involves cutting emissions from "sources" of greenhouse gases e.g. petrol cars and enhancing "sinks" which draw emissions down from the atmosphere e.g. forests.

nodes.label: biodiversity loss
nodes.description: Increasing air and water temperatures and altered precipitation patterns are affecting the structure, composition and functions of ecosystems. Resulting in loss of biodiversity that help support human well-being.

nodes.label: Drought-resistant crops
nodes.description: Drought-resistant crops are varieties of plants that are specifically bred or naturally adapted to withstand prolonged periods of low water availability.

nodes.label: desert community
nodes.description: Communities that live in the desert

nodes.label: non-timber forest sector
nodes.description: Collection and use of forest resources other than timber, such as fruits, nuts, medicinal plants, resins, and fibres

nodes.label: fossil gas
nodes.description: Fossil gas is a fossil fuel energy source which contains many different compounds, the largest component of which is methane. It is commonly known as natural gas.

nodes.label: Forest fire control
nodes.description: Fire Control is defined as all activities concerned with protection of the vegetative cover and structures from destruction by fire

nodes.label: carbon capture and storage
nodes.description: Technology that enables the capture and sequestration of carbon dioxide emissions from the atmosphere to help mitigate climate change.

nodes.label: coal
nodes.description: Coal is a combustible black or brownish-black sedimentary rock with a high amount of carbon and hydrocarbons. It is a non-renewable energy source and fossil fuel, and has four main types.

nodes.label: carbon cycle
nodes.description: The natural circulation of carbon among the atmosphere, oceans, soil, plants, and animals.

nodes.label: wildfire ash
nodes.description: The particulate residue remaining, or deposited on the ground, from the burning of wildland fuels and consisting of mineral materials and charred organic components.

nodes.label: economic sector
nodes.description: Area of the economy in which actors engage in identical or related activities.

nodes.label: deforestation
nodes.description: Removal of forest and conversion of the land to non-forest use, and is the direct human-induced conversion of forested land to non-forested land

nodes.label: fossil fuel
nodes.description: Fossil fuel is a generic term for non-renewable energy sources such as coal, fossil gas, crude oil, and petroleum products. Fossil fuels are carbon-based and release carbon into the atmosphere when burned.

nodes.label: forest degradation
nodes.description: Land degradation in forested areas, referring to the loss of the biological wealth of a forest.

nodes.label: agriculture sector
nodes.description: Activities that involve the cultivation of crops and raising of livestock for food, fibre, and other products essential for human life and industry.

nodes.label: biodiversity
nodes.description: The variability among living organisms from all sources and the ecological complexes of which they are part.

nodes.label: forest protected area
nodes.description: Effective protection of tropical forests can reduce biodiversity loss and enhance carbon storage, as they are among the most biologically rich ecosystems on earth.

nodes.label: terrestrial risk
nodes.description: Terrestrial means "of the earth" and relates to the ecological system that includes all living organisms and their interactions within land-based environments, such as forests, grasslands, and deserts.

kg_data.query: Which municipality is the largest in Brazil?
